items.title: Update deprecated postgres FloatRangeField field
items.body:
Hi,

I am using `Base64ImageField` field and I recently upgraded all of my packages and I found below error in my terminal.
```bash
  File "/xxx/serializers.py", line 1, in <module>
    from drf_extra_fields.fields import Base64ImageField
  File "/xxx/env/lib/python3.6/site-packages/drf_extra_fields/fields.py", line 256, in <module>
    ModelSerializer.serializer_field_mapping[postgres_fields.FloatRangeField] = FloatRangeField
AttributeError: module 'django.contrib.postgres.fields' has no attribute 'FloatRangeField'
```

Packages:
```bash
django-extra-fields    2.0.5

Django                 3.1
django-appconf         1.0.4
django-braces          1.14.0
djangorestframework    3.11.0
```

Let me know if I am missing any other packages to list out.

Do I need to use outdated packages for now or I can resolve it easily???

items.title: Upload wheels to PyPI
items.body:
Wheels (`.whl`) for this package are currently missing from PyPI. Could wheels be uploaded for the current and future releases?

Read more about the [advantages of wheels](https://pythonwheels.com/) to understand why generating wheel distributions are important.

To create a wheel along with source distribution:

```bash
(venv) $ pip install --upgrade pip setuptools wheel
(venv) $ python setup.py sdist bdist_wheel

# See dist/*.whl
```

To upload wheels:

```bash
(venv) $ pip install twine
(venv) $ twine upload dist/*
````

Should this version be unpinned and set to `>=`? Also in `requirements_dev.txt`. It seems like using this would force users to an older Pillow that is not maintained?

https://github.com/Hipo/drf-extra-fields/blob/d2d142f362448a0ed17394318f662f25f814a3b3/setup.py#L18

items.title: Release 2.1.0
items.body: It would be great if a new release could be pushed to PyPI that includes #119, that way users on Django 3.0 don't have to suppress a warning from this library. This is especially useful if they are using `-Werror` on their CI to catch unexpected warnings.

items.title: Drop support for django 1.x and python 2.7
Support for ListField(child=Base64ImageField())
items.body:
We would like to support uploading multiple base64 encoded files to a single PostgreSQL `ArrayField`. Is `ListField(child=Base64ImageField())` supported?

Skeleton example:

```py
# models.py
from django.contrib.postgres.fields import ArrayField

class Store(Model):
    files = ArrayField(models.FileField(upload_to='files', null=True, blank=True))
```

```py
# serializers.py
from drf_extra_fields.fields import Base64ImageField
from rest_framework.fields import ListField

class StoreSerializer(ModelSerializer):
    datasheets = ListField(child=Base64ImageField())

    class Meta:
        model = Store
        fields = '__all__'
```

```py
# views.py
class StoreViewSet(ModelViewSet):
    queryset = Store.objects.all()
    serializer_class = StoreSerializer
```

When I POST something like:

```json
{
    "files": ["<B64_FILE>"]
}
```

The response I see in the debugger when testing in `pytest` from the POST (and subsequent GETs) looks like:

```py
{
    "files": [None]
}
```

No files seem to be stored either.

Before investigating this further, I wanted to check if this was something that was officially supported or if there was some reason that `Base64ImageField` wouldn't be compatible with `ListField`?

items.title: DateTimeRangeField: 'tuple' object has no attribute 'isempty'
items.body:
I'm encountering an error when I try to use this library (2.0.3) with Django 3.0.3 and DRF 3.11.0.

I have a `Reservation` model with the following field:

```
class Reservation(models.Model):
    dates = DateTimeRangeField()
```

My serializer is similar:
```
class ReservationSerializer(serializers.ModelSerializer):
    dates = DateTimeRangeField()

    class Meta:
        model = Reservation
        fields = (
            "id",
            "dates",
     )
```

When I create a `reservation` object, and run the following code:

```
serialized = ReservationSerializer(reservation)
print(serialized.data)
```

I encounter this error:

```
======================================================================
ERROR: test_get_reservation (reservations.tests.ReservationViewTest)
----------------------------------------------------------------------
Traceback (most recent call last):
  File "/Users/jamestimmins/Work/Fullstack/ch5/reservations/tests.py", line 123, in test_get_reservation
    print(serialized.data)
  File "/Users/jamestimmins/.local/share/virtualenvs/ch5-Ukgt_zTP/lib/python3.7/site-packages/rest_framework/serializers.py", line 562, in data
    ret = super().data
  File "/Users/jamestimmins/.local/share/virtualenvs/ch5-Ukgt_zTP/lib/python3.7/site-packages/rest_framework/serializers.py", line 260, in data
    self._data = self.to_representation(self.instance)
  File "/Users/jamestimmins/.local/share/virtualenvs/ch5-Ukgt_zTP/lib/python3.7/site-packages/rest_framework/serializers.py", line 529, in to_representation
    ret[field.field_name] = field.to_representation(attribute)
  File "/Users/jamestimmins/.local/share/virtualenvs/ch5-Ukgt_zTP/lib/python3.7/site-packages/drf_extra_fields/fields.py", line 220, in to_representation
    if value.isempty:
AttributeError: 'tuple' object has no attribute 'isempty'

----------------------------------------------------------------------
Ran 11 tests in 1.562s

FAILED (errors=1)
Destroying test database for alias 'default'...
```

Have you all encountered this type of issue before? It's possible I'm just missing something simple, but I can't figure out why the datetime range is getting represented as a tuple.

Thanks so much.

items.body:
I have tried the Base64ImageField in Django serializers but in React Admin it returned with [Object object] value. Please rectify the issue. Thank you.

![Screen Shot 2020-02-12 at 12 58 56 PM](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/51570658/74304385-d0ff1580-4d97-11ea-9187-249c2b668264.png)

The example code in Django serializers:

```
class UploadedBase64ImageSerializer(serializers.Serializer):
    attachment = Base64ImageField(required=False)
        
class WorkRequestTestSerializer(serializers.ModelSerializer):
    WRNO = serializers.CharField(read_only=True)
    attachment = 'R0lGODlhAQABAIAAAAAAAP///yH5BAEAAAAALAAAAAABAAEAAAIBRAA7'
    attachment = UploadedBase64ImageSerializer(data={'attachment': attachment})
```

I use ImageInput in React Admin:

```
<ImageInput source="attachment" label="Attachment" accept="image/*">
   <ImageField source="src" title="title" />
</ImageInput>
```

items.title: Import error on Django 3.0
items.body: Django 3.0 has removed `django.utils.six`. As we are still using `six.text_type` and `six.string_types`, the imports fail.

items.title: RangeField doesn't aware of validators, that was applied to model field
items.body:
I've defined model like so:

```python
class SomeModel(models.Model):
    weight_range = IntegerRangeField(
        _('weight'),
        validators=(
            RangeMinValueValidator(WEIGHT_MIN_VALUE),
            RangeMaxValueValidator(WEIGHT_MAX_VALUE),
        ),
        **not_char_field_nullable,
    )
    # ...
```

My serializer class looks like so: 

```python
class SomeSerializer(serializers.ModelSerializer):

    weight_range = IntegerRangeField(label=_('Weight'), required=True)

    class Meta(ExpectedPartnerProfileBaseSerializer.Meta):
        model = SomeModel
```

Expected behaviour would be applying validators to serializer field, but it's not happening.

items.title: proposed new field: BinaryField
items.body:
Given DRF does not support BinaryField out of the box meanwhile many ask for being able to POST binary data, such as pandas.DataFrame.to_hdf on an external server or a pickled df etc. Its one of the topics it hardly exist any explicit solution to.

Perhaps there is a reason it does not exist, but I am unaware of such reason.

Would be super for everyday programmers to download drf-extra-fields and get an out of the box solution for getting access to BinaryField in a quick uncomplicated manner.

items.title: RangeField mutates initial_data
Auto file name generated by uuid4 can be blocked by adblockers
items.body:
Random names generated by drf-extra-fields include file names that end with `-ad0`, which is blocked by ublock origin and possibly other adblockers. Will create a pull request to increase the string length by 1 to avoid this issue.

See this [issue by me](https://stackoverflow.com/questions/57227131/images-that-fit-the-regexp-ad0-9-png-can-not-be-loaded-in-any-browser/57227395#57227395) on stackoverflow
https://github.com/Hipo/drf-extra-fields/blob/e33048bdba6e82ba3f61719466b73d50f8a695e2/drf_extra_fields/fields.py#L83

items.title: setup.py is missing the requirements
items.body: I think this was always an issue, but since most projects using this library already have django and drf installed nobody has noticed it. Except now pillow was added. I propose breaking the requirement file into requirements.txt and requirements-dev.txt and add the former to setup.py. Either that or hard-code the requirements into setup.py.

items.title: Make PIL optional
items.body: It seems a hard dependency to PIL [was added recently](https://github.com/Hipo/drf-extra-fields/commit/c6a05d6a6750e9dd894a6a598c1d8200e012feea) but not every field requires PIL and not all projects require PIL either. I think this requirement should be optional. Otherwise, we are forced to install the [PIL pre-requirements](https://pillow.readthedocs.io/en/stable/installation.html#building-on-macos).

items.title: BmpBase64ImageField(represent_in_base64=True) unable to handle null image
items.body:
If a have a model:

```py
class Project(models.Model):
    thumbnail = models.ImageField(upload_to='thumbnails', null=True, blank=True)

    # The real model had more data. This is a simplified version with just the thumbnail.
```

And a serializer so that users can upload images via Base64 and via as URLs:

```py
class ProjectSerializer(serializers.ModelSerializer):
    thumbnail = BmpBase64ImageField()
```

And another serializer so that users can export images via Base64:

```py
class ProjectExportSerializer(serializers.ModelSerializer):
      thumbnail = BmpBase64ImageField(represent_in_base64=True)
```

If a user doesn't want upload a thumbnail, they can POST to `ProjectSerializer`:

```json
{
  "thumbnail": ""
}
```

But when you try to pull down the `ProjectExportSerializer`, there is an uncaught exception:

```
Internal Server Error: /export-projects/
Traceback (most recent call last):
  File "/Users/user/.local/share/virtualenvs/backend2/lib/python3.7/site-packages/drf_extra_fields/fields.py", line 83, in to_representation
    with open(file.path, 'rb') as f:
  File "/Users/user/.local/share/virtualenvs/backend2/lib/python3.7/site-packages/django/db/models/fields/files.py", line 56, in path
    self._require_file()
  File "/Users/user/.local/share/virtualenvs/backend2/lib/python3.7/site-packages/django/db/models/fields/files.py", line 38, in _require_file
    raise ValueError("The '%s' attribute has no file associated with it." % self.field.name)
ValueError: The 'thumbnail' attribute has no file associated with it.
```

The function in question is:

```py
    def to_representation(self, file):
        if self.represent_in_base64:
            try:
                with open(file.path, 'rb') as f:
                    return base64.b64encode(f.read()).decode()
            except Exception:
                raise IOError("Error encoding file")
        else:
            return super(Base64FieldMixin, self).to_representation(file)
```

I think that `ValueError` should be caught from the `open` and return `""` in the case of `represent_in_base64`?

items.title: REST Framework 3.9.0 breaks tests
items.body:
https://github.com/Hipo/drf-extra-fields/blob/8c79bdc82a590402d7435996abfa90fd56cd85c7/tests/test_fields.py#L554-L556

The test expecting this output fails because the date format in the exception text was changed in DRF 3.9.0 from `YYYY[-MM[-DD]]` to `YYYY-MM-DD`.

items.title: Couldn't determine file format when used base64 for image upload
items.body:
Hello, I am new to this package, so please tell me if I am in right direction to implement this or not.

So I have integrated this package in my current project, I am implementing a simple image upload flow.

My user model is,
`
       ```
class User(models.Model):
             image = models.ImageField(required=False)
```
`
and my model serializer is ,
`
     ```
 from drf_extra_fields.fields import Base64ImageField
      from .models import User
      class UserSerializer(serializers.ModelSerializer):
           image = Base64ImageField(required=False)
        
            class Meta:
                 model = User
```
`

Now, from frontend I am sending image in base64 format, 
```
`
    {
        'image': 'data:image/jpeg;base64,/9 ......'
    }
`
```
 **But I am getting type error message,  'The type of the image couldn't be determined.'**
I have looked into code in _fields.py_, and I see the part causing me problem is 
`
 ```
class Base64FieldMixin(object):
      .....       
      def to_internal_value(self, base64_data):
            .....
            if isinstance(base64_data, six.string_types):
                 .........
                 if ';base64,' in base64_data:                                                                                                 
                       header, base64_data = base64_data.split(';base64,')
                 ......... 
                 # generate file_name
                  file_name = str(uuid.uuid4())[:12]  # 12 characters are more than enough.                                                     
                  # Get the file name extension:                                                                                                
                  _file_extension = self.get_file_extension(file_name, decoded_file)_ 
         
  class Base64ImageField(Base64FieldMixin, ImageField):
     .......
     def get_file_extension(self, filename, decoded_file):                                                                                
           extension = imghdr.what(filename, decoded_file)                                                                                  
           extension = "jpg" if extension == "jpeg" else extension                                                                          
           return extension
`
```
To my understanding this code is sending the new encoded file name to get extension which doesn't have any relation to extension. Thats why I get _None_  returned as _file_extension_
But if I replace that code simply with
```
`
      file_extension= header.split('/')[1]
`
```
and this works fine.


So actually I am confused which side is wrong in this scenario, frontend or backend code of this package? Am I sending the wrong base64 format , or is there something I didn't understand about current logic you guys have implemented. 
Please guide me.  And , honestly thank you for reading this big explanation.

items.title: Using header in get_file_extension
items.body: Why header is not used to get_file_extension. It can be passed as a parameter to get file extension.

items.title: Inconsistency in PointField
items.body:
For gis PointField, we are accepting lat and long as numbers/floats but converting them from model field to json as strings. Here https://github.com/Hipo/drf-extra-fields/blob/master/drf_extra_fields/geo_fields.py#L64-L67

*Input:*

```json
{
        "latitude": 49.8782482189424,
         "longitude": 24.452545489
}
```

*Output:*


```json
{
        "latitude": "49.8782482189424",
         "longitude": "24.452545489"
}
```

Do we have any reasoning for this? I think we should output lat and long as floats.

items.title: Declare more PyPI metadata
items.body:
Some of the important information for the package are missing from the PyPI metadata.

Please add the following in the PyPI metadata:
- Project homepage (`url`)
- Maintainer name (`maintainer`) and email address (`maintainer_email`)
- License grant (`license`)
- Trove classifier for license (in `classifiers`, the “License :: …” entry)

items.title: Declare support for Python 2 and/or Python 3
items.body:
The PyPI releases give no indication about support for Python 2 or Python 3.

Please update the releases so that the PyPI metadata explicitly says which versions of Python are supported.

items.title: Publish a release for each PyPI release
items.body:
Related to issue #9, the [GitHub releases page](https://github.com/Hipo/drf-extra-fields/releases) shows only “v0.1” and “v0.3”.

Please make a release at GitHub for each release published to PyPI (and vice versa also).

items.title: 'basestring' not defined under Python 3
items.body: Despite the `if` statement in `fields.py`, I get a `NameError` under Python 3. Perhaps the selection of the right string type should be done using a `try`/`except` to work properly.
